They have also started getting rid of the “little” people as I was also arbitrarily fired after working for the company for more than three years. Please be aware this is a definite possibility if you decide to work here. The sales team also has a constant turnover. The health insurance is more expensive and benefits are not as good as other health insurance companies.

review_title: Okay place for late-stage professionals. Not for innovation, change
pros:
- Pays well (health insurance $ goes far); 6% 401(k) match
- 40-45hrs/week is normal
- Nice people
- HR, benefits teams are nice and can help walk through benefit offerings, options
- People do care about the Cause, even though it may get muddled in the bureaucracy
- Employee Resource Groups are more vibrant than at other companies, although could use greater budgets.
cons:
- Not a good fit for young professionals. Avg. employee is in their 40s or 50s, looking to clock in & out , get good benefits, and have a stable job. For those trying to experience a fun, dynamic, or innovative culture, Cambia is not the place.
- Not agile. Pretends to be agile, but cannot escape the waterfall mindset and project funding/cost accounting approaches reinforce this.
- Internal advancement to middle and senior mgmt is difficult; bias towards external hires with national-company backgrounds for Dir, VP, SVP or C-Suite.
- Pay equity is an issue; if you come in at a certain pay and climb the ladder you will be leaps behind the comp. of someone hired into the role.
- Executive team is bad at managing change and remains detached from the experiences of managers and ICs.
- Meetings proliferate. You may only work 45h/wk but those hours may be packed with back-to-back mtgs

job_title: Clawed My Way to Upper Middle Management in Portland, OR
pros: As a well funded Blues plan, there are lots of resources and opportunities for interesting work and projects. Cambia is innovative for a health insurance company. There is good opportunity for growth and you can get promoted to Assistant Director based on just your department lead's discretion
cons:
The annual lay off cycle at Cambia means that the relationship can't really grow beyond a transactional level. It's always year to year and it's heartwrenching to receive all the emails about colleagues being laid off at the end of the year.

Cambia also struggles to execute. That's because leadership releases an objective in the form of a vision and directs everyone to implement the vision. There's no middle step of developing a strategy around the vision so there's always chaos as everyone fights for their interpretation of the vision to implement.

job_title: Consulting Research Analyst Associate in Seattle, WA
pros:
I’ve really enjoyed working at Cambia. The culture is friendly but challenging in a good way, the people are sharp and competent, and they really value work life balance, with good benefits. 

Employees and management really seem to care about what’s best for our customers, and try to create real action from our strategy and values. Leadership really listens to employees and wants everyone to succeed. 

The company has been very flexible and intentional with the COVID situation, even using the out-of-office time to redesign office spaces to be more collaborative and technology friendly to allow a flexible hybrid work environment when we return to office. The company is very focused on wellness too, providing a lot of resources and programs to employees, including virtual cooking classes, yoga classes, meditation sessions, and team activity challenges. 

I’ve also noticed a higher proportion of women in leadership here than in other companies, which is great. Cambia received some awards for equality and being a great workplace for women, and I think it definitely shows. 

I’ve been impressed so far with the company and look forward to growing here.
cons: Not many cons. I had hoped for a higher starting salary, but it’s reasonable.

review_title: Good company, difficult job position though
job_title: Customer Service Professional in Medford, OR
pros: Most people that work for Cambia are really nice and friendly. They provide good healthcare benefits and I feel like I am being paid fairly for someone who graduated from college a year ago. They are all about helping each other and teamwork, which I can appreciate. Sometimes we get bravo points for going the extra mile helping one of our team members, and we can use the points to get gift cards or gifts. Management usually looks towards the positive and they are all about future goals. I am a goal oriented person and positivity helps me get through my work day.
cons: This job is extremely stressful. It is mentally and emotionally exhausting. I feel like I have to put myself into a character almost to fully do my job. I drink 5 cups of coffee a day. We get surveyed by the members and that contributes to our stats. Stats are the be all and end all in the specific job position. It's really hard delivering bad news that a member may not want to hear, and you know they are already upset and you worry that because of dumb policies you are going to get a bad survey. You have to try to be positive and friendly in all situations with the members over the phone, because management almost wants you to pretend like you fixed all of the members problems. There are some problems you can help the member fix, but there are some that are totally out of your control and it's really hard when the members keep asking you why and there is not a solid answer. Resource desk helps most of the time, when there is a solid answer on something. There are 2 girls on Resource Desk that I personally feel are condescending about how they give information when I happen to get them, they make me feel dumb and try to flip the question I'm asking back on me. I don't like how every month we have a meeting with our supervisor and it's all about our stats, it's like the same meeting over and over again each month. It seems like these supervisor meetings are about pushing you to improve in certain areas, even if your stats good it is never enough. I wish they asked me more how I am doing in the supervisor meetings. I am smart and can do the job, but it is so extremely stressful and draining that I don't know how long I can do this.

pros:
Large company with a variety of opportunities.
Good work-life balance, no overtime.
Lots of layers of management, so little personal responsibility if that’s what you’re looking for.
cons:
With the new CEO transition, the company is in chaos. The ultimate direction is unclear- lots of conversation about “opportunities” and “growth” but the reality is consolidation and people leaving (by their own choice or otherwise).

Change was needed, because the company had been operating incredibly inefficiently and hemorrhaging peoples’ insurance premium money on layers of management and projects that went nowhere. It remains to be seen whether the situation improves over the long run.

Upper management (there’s a lot of it) tends to be hired in, rather than grown from within, and is completely disconnected from individual contributors.

job_title: Customer Service Representative III in Medford, OR
pros:
*The people you work with, make this job tolerable. 
*Most of the time you are left to take calls and help people with their questions. Depending on your supervisor, there isn't a lot of micro management. 
*There is a annual incentive that you get almost every year, which comes to about and extra paycheck
*The benefits aren't bad.  Medical, dental, vision, rx are standard, nothing too fantastic even though you work for an insurance company, you would think they would be better. 
*They contribute to your 401k, by matching up to 6%
cons:
*If you don't befriend the right people, you will not go any where. There is a clique of people that basically run the show there. If you aren't part of the inner circle, you are not going to advance. 
*Room for advancement is limited once you hit a certain point. There are 4 levels of Customer Service Representatives: 
   Customer Service Representative I
   Customer Service Representative II
   Customer Service Representative III
   Customer Service Ambassador 
It is pretty easy to get to level 3 with in 12-18 months, but after that, getting to the Ambassador level, which has a way higher pay grade than level 3, you better hope that someone gets fired, leaves, or you kiss the right persons butt in order to get that position.

review_title: Great ideas, Poor Execution and Leadership Accountability
pros: Lots of talented people. All the right assets to make a big play in health care. Pretty good benefits (the best 401k matching commitment I have experienced from an employer) and career opportunities if in a Regence market or near a regional hub.
cons: Career opportunities not good if outside of a Regence market / geography. Very Regence service area geography focused. Wants to be a national player but cannot break free from legacy baggage and myopic, in-Regence territory thinking. Business as usual, maintain the status quo and not invented here mentalities are prevalent despite the overwhelming messaging from the leadership to change. Little real accountability for enforcing or achieving real change and innovation. Lots of silos, fiefdoms and turf wars. Lacks a nationwide recognizable brand and a cohesive go-to-market strategy across businesses (lots of disjointed standalone solutions and duplication of effort / development) .

review_title: Very stabled company, good work & life balance, great pay & benefits, secure job
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
Incentive bonus and 401k are great compared to other major companies in Seattle area.  Below list of benefits are pros to the company.

Base Pay

Our salary program assures our base pay is market-competitive in all geographic locations where we operate. Your experience and skills help determine your initial base salary. 

Performance-Related Pay

Cambia encourages peak performance by setting company-wide goals. When goals are achieved, we share the success with a performance incentive.

Comprehensive Benefits

Full-time and part-time employees regularly scheduled to work 20 or more hours per week may participate in the following benefits programs starting on their first day of employment.
A choice of medical and dental plans for yourself, your spouse or domestic partner, and your eligible children.
Life and Accidental Death & Dismemberment insurance for yourself, your spouse or domestic partner, and your eligible children.
Short-Term and Long-Term Disability coverage
Health Care and Dependent Care Flexible Spending Accounts (FSA)
Mass Transit Company Subsidy
Transportation and parking spending accounts (CREA)
Legal/Financial Services Plan
401(K) Savings plan
Voluntary benefits: automobile, home insurance, pet insurance, Consumer Product Purchase Program, Identity TheftSmart Program, Critical Illness Protection Program
Paid Time Off (PTO)
Holidays/Floating Holiday
Bereavement Time
Jury/Witness Duty Time
Employee Assistance Program
Wellness programs: health, exercise and nutrition activities with rewards
cons: Health Insurance Plan for employees needs to be improved as working for a health care company.

pros: Good salary, benefits, but you have to pay to park. Nice cafeteria with interesting food, but seating is limited and uncomfortable. Nice workout gym but you have to pay to use it.
cons: Some managers were okay, mine were not - they didn't allow flex schedules or telecommuting even though company policy allows it. It really varies by group, but mine were petty, vindictive, and micro-managers. If you keep your head down and don't ask questions, you'll do fine. Work environment is not nice, looks like a mental hospital with metal doors that you have to badge in to. Managers get offices by the windows and everyone else has windowless cubes in the center. Each floor has a small break room but not all have a sink, just a table to eat at so most people eat at their desk.  It's really top management heavy - everyone is a Director. I had 1 team lead for a team of 2. Rarely met with the Director for our group, they always cancelled 1:1s, never attended group staff mtgs. Bad communication. Glad to be done with it.

pros: Work life balance, company culture.

review_title: Solid pay, a little behind as far as tech goes, but striving to improve.
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Pay is good, considering my position and experience (software developer). Benefits are generally great (401k especially), although the health insurance deductible is a little high compared to other companies. My particular team is very good. Most co-workers are very capable, the team functions well, my manager is on top of things but hands-off in a good way. However, I think I lucked out with my team in some ways.
cons: I've heard very mixed reviews from other tech workers in the company in other groups. A couple people have had poor management experiences, but surprisingly, the most severe of the two worked out in favor of the employee. It's a big company, so there are issues with bureaucracy--performance measurements that feel very redundant at times, old technologies that are hard to avoid using, etc. Office atmosphere is pretty boring, sometimes a little isolating, but they at least have a big facility upgrade planned (interior renovations). There's only so much you can do to try to spark comraderie among co-workers, so I don't fault them too much nor expect it to improve much, but I do feel like the upgraded interior will make people generally more willing to work in the office and more content while doing it.

review_title: Horrible Managers with no management skills
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Benefits are good. Work/Life balance id ok only if you are assertive.

Most of the people in this company are old time employees. So they try to form an old boys club and then boycott anyone who is a threat to them. job_title: Membership Eligibility Processor in Portland, OR
pros: Benefits, especially the employee incentive plan and employer contribution to the 401K plan.  The people in my department., especially my supervisor.  Convenient downtown location.  Recently remodeled workspaces (in Portland at least).  Good food in Trellis and Vine (though I could rarely afford it.)
cons: Change for its own sake-some changes are specific to Affordable Care Act, but others seem to be just for the fun of it.  Sometimes people are let go coldly and without notice.  The workspaces, although they are new and glitzy, can be noisy (open concept).  Work procedures have to be located using a search engine, which can be difficult to find when you are doing an infrequent or unfamiliar type of work.  It can be hard to get out of your department-I never was successful (I worked in group membership).  People who are promoted tend to be ruthless and very bottom line oriented.

review_title: Depends on the group you work with
pros:
The company is a good company, follows the ethics and mission pretty well.
There are many great teams and business units to work within, and there are some that are not so great - choose wisely.
The 401K and annual "bonus" program has been pretty spectacular the last 4+ years
The salary is competitive
The environment is pleasant, people are engaged and fun to work with
cons:
Meeting mandated delivery means the schedules are fixed for many projects, even though they try to operate under Scrum.
There are some "legacy" issues both in people and technology, moving slow and the "we can't do that" attitudes
Management keeps shifting about, don't be surprised when shuffled to a new manager and your goals for the year get lost along the way
They have a terrible time getting the projects defined and aligned during the first part of the calendar year, and most projects and budget start Jan 1 - putting everyone behind.
Obvious the top execs are taking loads of money

review_title: A company only out for a dime
job_title: Provider Customer Service in Tacoma, WA
pros: The only pro I can think of is the pay.
cons:
The way they treat someone with a medical problem is absurd. Myself, and another person had a severe medical issue & the only thing they said was in regards to going over breaks. As a verbal warning. 
The seniority plays a HUGE role. Don't ever try to report a manager, or managers friend for ANYTHING. oh boy will it be turned into your problem and get you in trouble. 

Hearsay should have no place in the work. Yet this company and gossip is what makes it or breaks it for you. I would recommend keeping to yourself as they will twist ANYTHING & EVERYTHING to their advantage to get you out. 

Exceeding past all your peers? Well if you're not in the cool guy crowd or in with all the managers watch your back. They will try to get you out as fast as they hired you. 

Have something you want to report? GET EVERYTHING IN WRITING & have a non biased third party there! If not they will believe the one with seniority & you won't have a chance to defend yourself.

pros: I would have given a 3.5 start review but that wasn't an option and I'm feeling generous so four it is. Great Benefits, Flexible work schedules,  on site coffee shops, cafeterias, restaurants close by, clean facilities. Depending upon your team/manager, many people have the ability to work from home occasionally up to half or even full time (this can be great for people who are self motivated but also often enabled unmotivated employees to slack on their responsibilities putting the workload on others). There's a significant amount of collaboration that crosses between departments and teams which is great.
cons: Little resolution to issues generated by Director and VP level staff. Low morale on some teams. Extremely high tension, executives not afraid to have yelling matches in front of their staff, unprofessional and belittling. Most of the director and above staff are male, little diversity. Significant unbalance in corporate spending habits from the top down.

pros: I was able to build a very successful program and I loved working with my team.
cons: Horrible boss who did NOTHING but parade her big ego and was despised by her boss, but because of politics was allowed to languish. I on the other hand, after nearly a decade of dedication and contributions -- including earning the organization awards and stellar reviews -- unceremoniously had my position "eliminated," under the guise of "budget." That was BS and other factors like age and ego were involved. I've landed fine, but I will never forgive the SVP who allowed that to happen, when she knew better -- who was really doing the work. Don't give too much if you work there, because you're vulnerable to whims and politics. It was seriously one of the most politically tense work environments ever encountered in nearly three decades of my career.

pros: Cambia has always had a flexible work culture and most managers allow for some remote work days and flexible hours. They are working to stay innovative and constantly trying new things, buying and investing in additional organizations and looking for the next big thing in healthcare.
cons: Flexibility is great, but unfortunately, this also means people are working later/longer than ever. My largest complaint is that it's a very hierarchical organization. Senior execs meet and have great ideas, but have no idea how to implement them and simply pass down grand plans without any transparency or conversation about expectation and how work actually needs to get done. There also seem to be multiple groups working on similar projects. Duplicative work gets frustrating.

review_title: Great vision for the future of healthcare but severe lack of execution, leadership and diversity
pros: Good benefits, nice facilities.  Great place to work if you are a white male.  Not a good place if you are a woman or a person of color. On the surface encourages innovation and diversity but all decision making is concentrated with a few senior management team members who are out of touch.
cons: A very white male dominated leadership team and culture. Cambia  will not be able to serve consumers or fulfill their vision unless the executive team learns how to lead and allows for diversity of gender, ethnicity and thought.  There are too many in roles of authority who are allowed to disrespect or undermine individuals with differing perspectives, background and gender.

cons: equal pay doesn't exist here... men get paid MUCH more money for the same job than women do, paying to park in downtown Portland is $300/mo with no assistance/reimbursement, benefits are VERY expensive (about 1/2 my check for my benefits package for family coverage) and it's not worth what i pay for it.

review_title: Not your typical old school non profit insurance company

cons: As a start-up, it is a fast paced environment...sometimes being nimble and quick means you can change your mind...daily, if you want. cons: None!  I am overjoyed to be a part of the cutting edge of healthcare innovation and it’s a thrill to come into work everyday!

job_title: Senior Developer III in Portland, OR
pros: It's a nice walk from the Max Red/Blue line. Some of the people there are really good devs.
cons:
Where to start.   
1. They have far too many managers. That spend far too many (expensive) hours in pointless meetings. 
2.  You can't get anything done there,  without consulting a bunch of 'managers' and filling out request form after request form ..and waiting 2 weeks for it to be approved.
3.  Dilbert lives here!    And Ratbert  is on the 14th floor. 
4.  They 'say' they are Agile ...  but they wouldn't know a successful sprint  if it bit them. 
5.  The code is  10 years old, written by various contractors over that time (they only recently started hiring FTE) and not documented.   If  you want to live  in javascript hell  and support an app from 2001 ...  good luck to you. 
6.  The managers are idiots  and couldn't  code their way out of a paper bag! They also make Top-Down decisions so watch out for the politics!

pros: Paid time off, and annual incentive program.
cons: Constant layoffs, not just annually. Most employees are working in fear of losing their jobs. Too many layers of management, and some lack understanding of direction. This is a strange culture of fear and lack of comradery. I am surprised that the rating is a 3. I would rate Cambia a 2. If you are looking for a company that you feel your experience and skills will add value, you might check out other companies before making this leap. Consider these reviews before making any employment decisions.

review_title: CMO creates incredibly toxic work environment
pros: Work from home culture. Some people and departments are functional, not the one I'm in.
cons: I have never worked in such a toxic environment in which the top leader in a large department creates such a negative, toxic environment. I watch employees around me being gaslighted, lied to, belittled and abused. The culture in this particular area is so bad it drives gossip, negativity, and poor morale. It's a shame, because some areas of the company seem quite nice, with good morale and camaraderie, but this department is so bad, I would not recommend it to my worst enemy, let alone a friend. There are office jokes among direct reports to the CMO having a support group to cope with the abuse. It is frankly stunning to me that executive leaders do not realize this is going on. Or perhaps they know and do not care. It's hard to tell.

pros: The work in enrollment is good and relatively calm.  Nothing exciting, but decent work.  My co-workers were nice and helpful.  Benefits were also amazing.
cons: Poor management and HR - I became very sick at the beginning of the year and was approved for FMLA.  From the time my FMLA began, my manager retaliated any time I had a covered appointment and harassed me until I finally put in my notice to get away from it.  It was too stressful dealing with illness and coming to work wondering how I would be harassed that day.  I spoke with HR a few times, but the issue was not resolved before I left.

review_title: Good place to work with a good heart and good people
pros:
Cambia has a great heart and it shows in the dedication to the member.  
Management gives some autonomy to contribute.
Working from home is awesome, but up to individual managers.
Macromanagement (for the most part).
cons:
IT infrastructure and tools are very archaic and broken.  Some of the worst tools (expense reporting, quarterly reviews, etc) I have ever used in a company.
Lots of meetings that are often pointless and a huge distraction.
You will spend a lot of time hacking PowerPoint presentations.
Inconsistent policies.
Lots of time talking strategy, not much time left to do work.
Overwhelmingly complex and restrictive travel policy - the craziest I have ever seen

pros: Good 401k plan and very nice co workers. My team lead is very cool person. He trust everyone and give each team member their own space.
cons: Very less pay and yearly bonus. Few managers are racist. They always see fault in team members to give low feedback that would not give raise to the paycheck. Star rating team members raise is meager. For software developers who want to work on cutting edge technologies then Cambia is NOT for you. I wonder how the senior management does planning for the work estimate. Cambia has very poor planning record and it continues. Work load is drought one year and floods the next cycle. Work visa permit candidates should refrain from joining this company.

review_title: Not a good place to work if you want to build a career.
pros: Nice office with views of Portland. Onsite gym is nice along with the cafeteria. Pay is comparable to  Portland salaries.
cons: Managers at this company lack leadership and training. It seems that Cambia will make anyone a manager without ensuring that person can lead a team. A lot of employees are immature and it appears that once someone is hired, they will not be fired, no matter if their experience and performance is lacking. There is no room for growth unless someone leaves. I would not recommend this company for someone looking to build a career.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Lewiston, ID
pros: Benefits on day one of employment, paid training and discounted membership for the on-site gym.
cons: Extremely Micromanaged and pay not commensurate with the frequently increased expectations.  This is a very stressful position and it is exacerbated by a corporate culture that feels punitive and out of touch with what  those on the front line of customer contact contend with each day.  It is impossible to get approved time off and you are not able to apply for higher positions (or get decent shift hours) if you have too much "unplanned time off".   High turnover rate.

review_title: Negotiate before you accept - and then beware
pros: Great 401k bonus and short term incentives. Flexible work schedule
cons: If you want to grow, this is not the company for you. If you don't negotiate your salary before you start you will not get a raise. Great managers are few and far between. The culture between departments swings wildly from fun to suppressive.  Expect your first year to be completely lost to confusion  while having unrealistic work expectations pressed on you. Also, don't make any waves just before the short-term incentives.

review_title: Poorly Managed, Rife With Insecure Ladder Climbers
pros: Cambia offered a competitive benefits package, including 401(k) matching, health insurance, and a monthly transportation stipend. Their telecommuting policy was also fairly flexible, and over my three years an increasing number of people took advantage of the ability to work at their own pace, at the expense of the office's community. Pay was a bit low compared to industry standards, but it was acceptable (although advancement opportunities were limited).
cons:
There are two different kinds of people who will find success at Cambia Health Solutions:

1) The rules-oriented mild-mannered type that strives to avoid conflict, even if this leads to a loss of individuality or respect.
2) The bloviating middle manager, intent upon micromanagement, business buzzwords, and valuing appearances over ability.

This is not a company that will work with you to reach your goals. Sadly, it is one of those "saying less is more" companies, where even anonymously sharing your critical insights or your feedback about managers will lead you down the (albeit slow, thanks to bureaucracy) path of termination. The upper ranks are comprised of traditionalists, who will cast disparaging remarks towards analysts with longer beards or messy cubicles, even if the person in question does not have a client-facing role. Whether this is by deception or design, raises and career advancement occur at a snail's pace, giving the false impression of hope and forcing the individual to wait quarters to years.

And don't let anybody fool you about their message. The common refrain is that people want to "make a difference" and "be a catalyst to transform healthcare". This company is not innovating in the manner that they claim to be. They are further contributing to the mess that is our healthcare system by keeping incompetent brown-nosing micromanagers in their ranks. And when I say micromanagers, I mean the kind that spend 30 minutes of 1:1 time explaining to a lifelong computer user that they have to "click the save icon otherwise the document won't save". Want another example? How about the kind that spends an hour during a formal review of a multi-million dollar hospital model arguing about which shades of colors to use in the reporting deliverable instead of the integrity of the analysis? Change is slow because companies like Cambia Health Solutions hire the loudest individuals over the most competent.

review_title: Good cause, great benefits, but upper management is a complete disaster
pros:
Great location
Good pay and great benefits
cons:
There are 2 or 3 times as many non-doers than doers. Any given meeting, will have a couple of project managers, a few team managers, a few delivery managers and 1 or 2 developers and in many cases, no QA people at all. 
Upper management knows the problems on ground, but pretends like they don't so they don't have to actually do any work. But they are all busy in meetings, drawing colorful pictures, presenting recycled powerpoint slides, coming up with catchy jingles as annual goals, but instead of working towards the goals, they just come up with new ones.

pros: Cambia Values are real - this company gives more time and money back to the communities they serve than any company I've ever worked for.  People are good and want to do their jobs well. Great 401k and bonus program. Healthcare is in a very important period of change right now - work for the solution!
cons: Too many layers of management giving direction, often find ourselves duplicating efforts or working the same problem in different ways. Teams feel very stressed and demands are high. Haven't figured out agile well enough yet. Training and growth is limited.

review_title: Lots of changes, but great opportunities and flex to be had
pros: Great work-life balance; can work from home if your boss allows it. I have had numerous bosses though and the guidelines around this soft perk have changed with each one of them. The Portland office has a great cafeteria and fun downtown location. They also pay top of the market, from what I can tell.
cons: Constant personnel changes; within six months everyone who was on my team when I started was gone due to layoffs, transfers or they left the company. Salaries are great, but the insurance coverage is just so-so and you have to pay for parking in downtown locations. Portland office is $10.50-$12.00/day so keep that in mind when you negotiate your salary. They offer a discounted transit pass for $20/day.

review_title: Management is stuck in doing things the way they have always done it, where mediocrity is encouraged and praised.
pros: Working from home one day a week.
cons: Management values docility over ingenuity. It is impossible to implement processes that would keep them compliant or even in the 21st century, they would rather keep it status quo then change, even if that change would save them money in the long run. They do not provide educational opportunities or training, so if you want to expand your skills or knowledge - you are on your own.

pros: The checks cleared. The cafeteria was really great and had wonderful soups.
cons: Incredibly toxic environment with terrible training, passive aggressive managers and significant backstabbing / tribal mentalities. Jobs were consistently created for contractors that were told would last at least a year and only actually scoped out for 3 months. Many business ventures were purposely set up to fail - possibly for tax write-offs? Incredibly hostile upper management that seemed at odds with each other at all times. Paid $20/hr less than identical positions at other companies.

review_title: Great benefits, too many measures and metrics.
job_title: Software Quality Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: The benefits (i.e., transportation subsidy, 401K, yearly bonus, work from home, training opportunities, casual dress) are great. The team sizes are perfect for an agile environment.
cons: Too many product owners with little education of their responsibilities as a Scrum team member. Business and IT have a big wall between them, but it slowly breaking down. Time tracking is ridiculous, as is the continual change in requirements (often ambiguous). Too many meetings which are often unproductive and intrusive on real work time.

review_title: Do your research and ask your friends - Good place to 'Retire in Place', as long as you can deal with a Culture of Fear
pros: Most all coworkers are great to work with - although there is a significant portion that have 'retired in place'.  Have an annual 'incentive' program if the company meets its goals.  If you are just starting your career or looking for a place to put in your time before you retire (meaning that you are willing to put up with being considered an interchangeable "resource' instead of a person), this place is for you.
cons:
Annual layoffs around the holidays each year are so much of the culture that they are called the annual 'Christmas Presents'.  Line staff openly uses the words 'Toxic', 'Culture of Fear', and 'Passive-Aggressive management' in day-to-day conversations.  Some directors are openly put down in public by other directors.

Appearances are more important that delivery.  Should a health care payer be run by a doctor or a lawyer?  CEO is the latter and more interested in his political career.  Dollars drive decisions.

Have been doing a lot a 'come work for us' social media in the past year to backfill all the good people now that the economy has improved.  Training program is in name only - career development is a once a year conversation with your manager as a checkoff item at your annual review.  Training is available, as long as it does not cost anything and it is on your own time.

Do your research, ask your friends, and carefully consider if the cool-aid is a flavor you can deal with.  Just go in with your eyes open.

review_title: I started working there at the end of last year they cared about their employees.
job_title: Provider Customer Service in Tacoma, WA
pros:
When I worked there - they had great benefits.  The cafeteria had a nice selection and the different shifts were staggered enough to find something that fits you. They let you decide what you wanted out of your experience. 
At least on the surface they had all the right tools for a comfortable work place.  They used personality assessments to help understand and work with their employees and they had a system for students or medical problems to work part-time for a while. 
The training was extensive and by the time you were helping real doctors and health professionals with insurance claims you feel confident in your knowledge.
cons:
It's all crap.  By the time I was let go,  the turnover rate had hit the roof and they could no longer keep long-term employees which is what made their company so great to work for.  
They no longer cared about their customers either.  The co-workers I left behind are all but gone from the company entirely. 
I developed a condition and got rushed to the hospital from the floor of the company.  Because of my insurance I had to wait days and weeks before I could even set appointments but I did not mind.  I worried about my job. I didn't know what was wrong with me and it looked like it was going to take a while to find out. I was working part-time and needed constant breaks but I kept coming in every-day.  
I asked them about my job and if my position was in danger.  They promised to let me know. 
They let me know the day of our reviews - they fired me.  
They fired me and because of that,  I had no insurance.  It took even longer to find out that what I had was Fibromyalgia.  I would sue - but it has been too long.

pros: Even though Cambia is a very large company, people are very friendly and there is much cross departmental and company teamwork.  Most anyone can be leveraged to support you and so many genuinely care that you get what you need to make projects a success.  The leaders of our company are the right fit and I feel they have all of our members and employees in mind while making decisions.  As a whole we have strong values and I believe the majority of people wake up leading with those values in mind.  Our company looks out for your family and future - they generously have created employee benefits that surpass other companies - parental leave benefits are much better than other company's I have seen, terrific 401k match, wellness programs and support - the list could go on. Another benefit is growth from within by way of well-designed programs to develop their people.  And for me, great work life balance.
cons: If you are in the suburbs, it can take 2.5hrs (round trip) to get to/from the office via transit.  I have opted to work from home several days so I can start working right when I wake up- the commuting takes away from both work and family. WFH isn't an option available to everyone.

review_title: Pretty darned good...5+ years here so far
pros: Lots of opportunity.  Lots of experience.  Lots of platform exposure.  Work from home.
cons: Middle management is a political s---hole.  Minimize exposure and life is good as an individual contributor.  I have had 4 outstanding managers, 1 good manager, and 2 terrible managers here (lot of re-orgs and manager turnover plus couple of job moves I made = 1 new manager per year on average...would prefer 2-3 years per manager).

job_title: Customer Service Professional I in Burlington, WA
pros: 17 Days of PTO, more after year 2.  Set schedules. Kind supervisors. They don't require a certain number of calls per hour. They value first call resolution more than a quick handle time. Very understanding of new  people.
cons: Busy, fast-paced call center (which I enjoy, but not everyone will flourish in that style). My only negative is that Cambia does pay less than our rivals, though not dramatically so.

pros: Salary and benefits are pretty great. Individual contributors (anyone outside of management/leadership) are mostly talented and great to work with.
cons: Cambia is controlled by the cash cow that is the for-profit Regence Health Plan. The entire company is ran by industry dinosaurs. Cambia has zero empathy for the people they exist to serve - both the public and their employees. The company is inundated with old corporate IT and clunky, disjointed DHS companies.

pros: Good place to work if you're comfortable with the status quo. Livable wages. Generally very predictable with occasional layoffs. I've made two good friends and five acquaintances I trust in work settings.
cons: I spend most of my time navigating the politics and covering my tender parts. My division is centralizing management functions in one city and inventing new "regional" directorships with authority over the management in the three other states. My career path (along with a many other managers) involves changing cities or divisions.

pros:
Nonprofit health insurance gives warm fuzzies.
Lots of positive change over the last 6 years in both technology and attitude.
Attracts lots of people who care.
Diverse workforce with involvement in all sorts of activities (PRIDE, Habitat for Humanity, etc).
cons:
Sometimes upper management layers lose track of reality.
Our nonprofit status only applies to Regence (the insurance biz). The other companies under the umbrella are not nonprofit.
Some projects are ultra-high visibility (member site), which can be stressful.

review_title: Disorganized, backstabbing, constant turnover and dishonesty in management
pros: there are no pros here other than if you need a paycheck and can tolerate high stress and game playing by supervisors
cons: pay is lower than average for same positions elsewhere, low raises, dishonest management which is constantly changing (some fired, some quit), low moral due to being treated poorly, total chaos constantly because supervisors don't know what they are doing, list goes on and on... bad technology and systems, high stress and no reward. They preach ethics and don't have any.

review_title: Struggling with a New Business Environment
pros: Highly engaging culture; Open to creative ideas; Employees generally feel valued; Strives for excellence in operations; Huge emphasis on ethics, security, privacy; As a not-for-profit, they really look out for the membership (subscribers); Trying to make healthcare affordable and sustainable; Financial ratings are high.
cons: Cost reduction almost to the point of diminishing returns; Soaring healthcare costs have put the company in a pinch; Questioning whether the business model can support the changes brought by the ACA;

review_title: Promising company with room for improvement
pros:
Flexible work location and hours, with core block from 9a-3p to enable collaboration.
They give serious consideration to healthy workplace and ergonomics.
Increased use of agile methodologies.
Access to training and encouragement to continue self-development.
Love the articulated values and intended culture.
cons:
Only partially agile. 
The required tools we use for planning and tracking are mined for metrics that are misleading and misunderstood by senior management.
Sudden departures of middle management are disconcerting.
Difficult to find an HR representative when you need one.
Too many departures from stated values.

review_title: Cambia looks best in your rear view mirror.
pros: The pay and benefits are on par with other Blue Cross companies, which are a little better than what you get at smaller carriers. The Portland and Seattle offices are right downtown, which I liked (don't know much about the SLC and Boise offices). The online training courses let you get familiar with a wide variety of software apps. There aren't many positions that require much hard work or brains. The company seems to be dumbing down the work as much as possible. If you're barely competent and quietly swallow your weekly ration of disrespect, you can usually hang around making a decent living for several years. If you have a talent for office politics, you can be a superstar. It also appears the Online Reputation staff is keeping themselves busy (hi guys!).
cons: It is the insurance business, which isn't very exciting, and the technology is always a hot mess. There are entirely too many weasels and weaselettes including managers who sabotage their own people. Between the politics and sloppy work ethics, it's frustrating when you need cooperation to do your job. There have been several rounds of restructuring and layoffs over the years. Lately the restructuring includes centralizing functions across state lines. Departments that used to be local, self-contained enterprises are getting more layers of management located in other states. That means more conference calls every week and reporting to (and getting judged by) weasels you rarely see. And in the back of your mind, you never know which functions are getting outsourced next.

pros:
I took a job at Cambia with some concern going into it. I had heard it was a slow moving company and not a great enivornemnt. After being here for 6 months, I have no plans in leaving.

- Excellent compensation across the board, with a nice annual bonus
- Supportive of work life balance, able to work remotely 1-2 days a week
- Knowledgeable team, hard working leaders
- A lot of room for advancement 
- Prioirtizes diversity and community involvement
cons: - I dislike their health insurance options ironically, seems like there are a lot of out of pocket costs once your utilize all of your HSA

review_title: DHS Operations Manager Role... Best Summer ever...
job_title: Operations Manager in West Portland, OR
pros:
Loved the creative, high energy environment. Great investment in technology, environment and employee satisfaction/engagement. Loved the employee gym and real commitment to healthy employees. Loved the uber cheap, healthy, locally sourced cafe. Location was great. Work was challenging but creative. Great infrastructure to support startup growth. Lots of room to grow.  My colleagues were ambitious, talented and diverse.

The IT, concierge/security, and HR department/roles were the best I've ever seen and now the model to which I've measured every employer since.  Outstanding commitment to technology, efficiency of tools, and avoidance of downtime.  Love this place!
cons: Many of the startup leaders come from operational roles and lack basic leadership skills.  This was tough because there was no peer support for my business leader in her direct peers - blind leading blind. The few resources DHS gave for coaching, devt, and support of business founders were outstanding but swamped.  My business founder had no idea how to talk to customers or lead a strategy and that's ultimately why I left.  I wasnt my place to do it for her - and she wasn't able to follow my lead (it wasn't appropriate given her role as business founder and mine as operations manager.)   My pay was decent - much less responsibility, no direct reports, etc., than I have usually, but ultimately I accepted another offer at a health system that came with a significant raise, bigger scope (director), supporting a team.  I loved my summer at DHS working for this startup and I miss the people, the environment and the work (in that order) very much... I'd highly recommend this place to anyone looking to learn and grow, help in very important work of transforming healthcare through innovation; as long as you are strongly self led and autonomous.  If you're new in your career and looking for a mentor, look elsewhere.  You could find one in a peer but not necessarily in the leaders of DHS businesses.  Cambia leadership is good though...HR, IT functions best I've ever seen.

pros: Compensation was good.  Great bonuses.
cons: They have a huge code base writen by short term contractors so it is all over the place.  There is no time to learn the monsterous systems and no one has time to train you, but you will definantly have deadlines.  You'd better make a short term messy fix, against all best practices and common sense, but what else can you do?

pros: The direct health solutions "businesses" and incompetent management haven't run the entire company out of business yet.
cons: Nothing good to say about this company. It exploits its profitable businesses to subsidize its delusions of start-up greatness, while using up and spitting out employees rather than dealing with -- or even acknowledging -- any of its many management and operational problems.

pros: Nice bonuses, friendly in halls, office is in walkable area downtown, culture respectful towards bike commuters, there's a nice private health club for employees that costs very little to join
cons: Not a mentoring culture, very political environment undermines risk taking, they lay off lots of people every October in a sneaky way without talking about it from the top, good people in manager and director roles quit a lot and leaders don't address it at all/say there may be something wrong with how they manage

pros:
There's a strong vision for how the company wants to change healthcare.
People want to do the right thing.
The work is challenging, and there are lots of problems to solve.
cons:
Company doesn't always know how to turn ideas into reality.
Leadership doesn't always know how to prioritize key initiatives.
Organization currently lacks a unified, long-term strategic planning process.

pros: Fast-paced and varied work. In Strategic Communications you bounce around writing, graphic designing and managing the website. I started part-time and moved to full-time as an intern. I also work with great mentors and learn a lot about in-house communication.
cons: I'd like to work more closely with leadership, but in a big company it's understandable that interns work more with coordinators and managers.

pros: The corporate values that the higher up executives try to promote, the part time work from home,  being challenged, intelligent, hard working, and kind supervisor, and having a living wage
cons: crowded cubicles, noise, little diversity of thought, minimal diversity of employees at this location

pros: The company has innovative ideas and its c-suite leaders mean well. The pay and benefits are generous. The people are also great to work with.
cons: It's the middle management that is poorly trained as leaders and are not supported which gets in the way of getting anything done. Some of the senior middle leaders are toxic.

review_title: Great cause, struggles with focus and strategy
pros: Non-profit health insurance is focused on the customer experience, strong ethically backbone, pays well, offers training and development to its people, financially strong
cons: Struggles with strategic vision and focusing attention.  Senior leaders are asked to make too many low level decisions and therefore aren't providing the vision and direction needed to deliver to the cause.

review_title: Great people, but they need more support
pros: Excellent employee benefits, front-line people are wonderful to work with.  Co-workers are motivated to do the right thing to reduce health care costs and improve the member experience.
cons: Management, particularly upper management, is somewhat disconnected from the day-to-day realities of what it takes to get the necessary work done, and done well.

review_title: The IT Department at Cambia (AKA Regence) is horribly and hopelessly broken. Avoid at all costs!
job_title: Manager, Technology Strategy in Portland, OR
pros: Can't think of one thing that is a pro.
cons:
Processes are broken - they are trying to jump to scrum with absolutely no clue what that means,
Systems are broken - open source with no clear reference architecture is a formula for diaster,
People are thrashing - no clear accountability and no desire to be held accountable for delivery, and
Leadership is entrenched and clueless - Director and VP level needs to be removed in their entirety.

pros: Great benefits package; you can work there for a long time if you wish
cons: Upper management completely out of touch with workers; projects cancelled regularly; lip service paid to agile and cloud but reality is waterfall and too much on-prem; Mac laptops poorly supported, locked down

pros:
- Huge opportunity for impact within company and externally in health care / solutions; definitely not your typical health insurance company
- Company is very committed to innovation and surfacing new ideas
- Kind, values-driven culture; enjoyable and smart colleagues
cons:
- Portland is definitely the hub; travel required if you are more senior and working in another location
- Lots of process / compliance due to industry can feel challenging

review_title: It could be worse but it should be much much better.
pros: The biggest pro is that its a job (I know a several people who don't have one). They pay livable wages and offer health and life insurance. The actual work isn't that hard most of the time. The management has improved after some retirements.
cons: The pecking order has been set for a very long time and it never changes. Regardless of how well I do my job, I'm never going to get promoted because I'm not one of the "chosen" ones. There's not much respect and it wears you down. You can't trust management.

review_title: Always reorganizing, but nothing much seems to change
pros: They provide a competitive salary and good annual bonus if the organization meets its metrics. Working from home is a nice plus.
cons:
Health benefits could be better. Ever changing management styles. Annual layoffs around Christmas can lead to a stifling environment. Environment seems to be getting toxic.

Integrating new systems is nearly impossible, not sure if it's a business issue or an IT problem, likely a bit of both!

pros: Good compensation, incredible flexibility, fantastic benefits, challenging work, very stable Company.
cons: Huge organization that is slow to react to change, inefficient (due in part to decentralization) and with a lot of recurring layoffs.

pros: Pay was good and fellow employees helpful.
cons: Management was terrible.  Very inexperienced and negative.  Wanted to do Agile Scrum with no Product Owner then blamed Dev team when work was not completed ontime.  Refused to let employees work from home even though they had no teammates on site.  Just poorly ran business and management. Beware not good.

review_title: Great mission but struggling with execution
pros: Great salary and benefits.  The mission of the company is great.  The company is working hard to transform from a traditional health insurance company to a direct health solution provider.
cons: While the company vision is clear there is a lot of confusion and mixed signals about how to execute on the mission.  Frequent leadership changes and immature corporate governance exacerbate the challenges.

job_title: Senior Analyst/Lead Analyst in Portland, OR
pros: Good pay and benefits for Portland market.  Some good people who needed a paycheck landed there.  Good location for bike commuting from east or west side.  Close to downtown and river front so you can get away from the office as often as you like (and you'll need that).
cons:
Finance is managed by former consultants and others with no formal finance training or experience, with hilarious results.  There is a lot of made up stuff that you wouldn't find in any other finance department anywhere and will leave you shaking your head.  Lack basic controls so they have an army of people whose only job seems to be to find mistakes and create a pool of people they can fire when anything goes wrong.  In short, they haven't a clue what they're doing.  The work is not meaningful and there are no clear roles and responsibilities.  The top guys in finance like to order people around and are constantly reorganizing and changing your responsibilities without a care what employees think.  Turnover is high.  Morale is low.

Overall the company is hemorrhaging cash in their core business all the while investing huge sums (hundreds of millions) on goofy health apps that nobody uses and other pet projects of the top executives.  Non-profit healthcare has huge profits that they have to spend on frivolous things instead of reducing premiums, so it's a huge contributor to the cost of healthcare in this country.  So don't be fooled by the "non-profit" banner and all the advertising about how "member-focused" they are.  They have an army of people dedicated to reducing what claims they'll pay and they could care less about people and their medical conditions.  It's a national shame.

job_title: Corporate Communications Writer in Portland, OR
pros: Good pay and benefits; good locations in Pacific Northwest. Focus on technology and consumer retail focus in health care, though health insurance still pays the bills.  Lots of opportunity to plot new career path inside the company.
cons: Highly matrixed organization. Nothing is simple. Everything is complicated. Lots of contractors  and some off-shore sourcing. Shifting focus means periodic RIFs and workplace "adjustments."

pros:
Good Benefits
Clean Work Environment
Nice Gym
cons:
No Integrity in Mid To Senior Executive Management
No Resource Support
Don't honor whats discussed as work or in offer letter

pros: Stable company. Matches charitable donations by 50%. Pockets of excellent people. Doing incredibly innovative things to change healthcare.
cons: Hypocritical values.  What's written and displayed are contradictory.  Behavior displayed by some executives sets a dysfunctional and dis respective tone through parts of the organization.  IT is appalling.

review_title: Potential for growth, however bogged down with bureaucracy
job_title: Health Care Services Analyst in Portland, OR
pros: Well capitalized, in an exciting industry (health care), opportunity to work at the nascent stage of startups, downtown location, salary, benefits
cons: Very bureaucratic, conservative, people don't seem all that happy. There are a number of people who are just there for the paycheck.

pros:
The benefits are good.
The people are great.
Downtown location is perfect.
The Trellis and Vine have amazing food.
cons: Constant reorganization, downsizing, and outsourcing.  It feels like a company on life support.

job_title: Accounts Receivable Specialist in Tacoma, WA
pros: Cambia is a great place, great benefits, and some perks.
cons: Middle management having too much power and no repercussions for management not treating employees respectfully and equally.

review_title: Dreary work propelled by a lack of vision
pros:
Some opportunities for working remotely
Salary is comparable to other companies in the industry
cons: Long term employees are rooted in old ways of thinking, lack of clarity as to job expectations (i.e. I was expected to design my own job, but got castigated when it somehow did not meet undocumented expectations), "cliquish" behavior among groups of female employees

review_title: Horrible management culture. Bullying and retaliation is common, and enabled by HR. No  employee relations policies.
pros: PTO, parental leave, and location convenience
cons:
Horrible, horrible management. It is not uncommon for employees to be bullied and retaliated against by management for something as simple as asking a question they do not like.  I can only assume that this is because people are promoted from entry level positions to management positions (including  departmental directors) with zero business management experience or education.  Go to HR about any of this and I guarantee it will get spun into how the employee is the bully. 

Their annual review process is completely based on how your manager likes you... nothing to do with your actual work. Huge discrepancies in pay practices, and if you try to go to HR to correct any concerns they will redirect you to your supervisor and then ignore you if you try to reach out to them when the issue is not resolved.  They routinely place employees under management where there is a clear conflict of interest. Employees are made to do work outside their purview, with no training. If you bring this up, they will say "other duties as assigned" is in your job description. 

There is ZERO ethics in data reporting. As someone with a statistics background, it's disappointing to see how they twist reporting numbers to reflect much better departmental and employee performance than the reality.

review_title: Run fast and far...in the other direction
pros: The office is convenient to mass transit.  The company promotes commuting by bike, and healthy lifestyles.  Nearly all worker bees are highly competent, amiable, professional, and caring people.
cons:
Employee development is spotty, some groups value it and others don't give it a second thought.  Management coaching does not occur until after one year, which is especially troubling for new people managers managing new employees.  There is no new employee orientation, and team building events are rare.

The employee handbook does not require managers to create training and development plans or administer performance improvement plans; many employees write their development plans after-the-fact.  Fully successful reviews can be followed within a few weeks by termination notice for lame and changing reasons (they are in cost-cutting mode this month).  This cycle repeats itself every year.

Leadership abilities of VPs and EVPs range greatly.  I wouldn't follow some to the cafeteria, while I'd follow others into a lopsided military campaign.

Although the company has a telecommute policy, many employees are expected to work in the office to justify a recent renovation, which turned 9' x 6' cubicles with 6' walls into 6' x 6' cubicles with 3' walls.  Picture yourself in a overpopulated petting zoo while trying to talk on the phone.

I witnessed wasted resources...$50k purchase of software that was never used and projects with 1000+ hours of effort before being abandoned due to politics.  Agile project management is a hit and miss effort.

Novel ideas are discouraged if you are not a long-term or "connected" employee.  This is a target rich environment for grad school business cases.

I had much higher job satisfaction and sense of accomplishment as a contractor.

review_title: Overworked, placed top 20% in company, was rewarded with 3% increase. Left company.
pros: Smart people, I could work from home since the Seattle office was sold and my job moved remote. No problem!
cons: Disconnected from reality of job market. I easily found an upgraded job for more than 20k what they were paying.

pros: Good benefits, 401k match, year end bonus. Generally pay really well in the finance org.Great work life balance.
cons: It's insurance, it's not for everyone (i.e. it can be really really boring). Often times it takes a long time for processes to change. Communication from mid level management of what's expected for a promotion isn't very clear.

pros: Pays very well and is progressing towards latest cloud technology, like AWS.
cons: The culture is very challenging to work as an Agile shop. Budgeting and requirements planning are still very waterfall like and so it becomes difficult to operate effectively as an Agile development organization.

review_title: Ineffective management / highly political / good benefits
job_title: Software Engineer IV in Portland, OR
pros: The salary is competitive and you can negotiate with them. The yearly bonus is nice when the company does well. Health insurance isn't bad. They have a high deductible plan, but load up an HSA card that you can use for medical expenses.
cons:
I saw a couple of concerning privacy issues in 2019 including the public exposure of PII of over 200 users (names and emails). Another individual at the company emailed claims and payment data for 25 users to a university researcher outside the company. Legal and privacy got involved in both cases and then the issues were buried. Both employees are still working at the company. I brought up both issues with the CEO and chief security and privacy officers, but never heard back.

Cambia is a highly siloed and can be a highly political environment. The CEO and COO have arguably wasted tens of millions of subscriber dollars building a cloud platform (Janus) and on a flagship product (Journi) that lacks a discernible value proposition. In addition, leadership cannibalized other products like Health Pass and MedSavvy to try and add some value to Journi.

Due to multiple leadership failures in my group, we lost a VP, a Director and a couple of software engineers in a few months time. When I was there I really believed that Cambia had high ethical standards. After my experience there, I was saddened to find that we did not end up sharing the same values.

review_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
pros: Being part of realizing great vision for changing Healthcare in USA to  help provide better treatment outcomes for consumers at less cost. Working shoulder-to-shoulder with a core group of incrediblycapable and dedicated individuals who are making the vision reality.
cons: Still much inertia in business and IT process change

review_title: Whole lot of talk...so little to back it up.
pros: Health insurance, paid time off, and somewhat flexible schedule. Offers other employee benefits; i.e. 3 weeks paid maternity leave, some positions are work from home.
cons:
Supervisors and managers at lower levels are unqualified, and undereducated for the positions they hold.  Unfair pay and promotion practices. I have personally witnessed employees having to apply, interview, and even have writing assignments to get a level promotion within a position, and then with another employee (not some great worker) they will just be given the same promotion.  I have personally witnessed bullying by management when they do not understand the subject being discussed (because they're not qualified anyway) and feel intimidated by the subject matter.  Management makes decisions as a reaction and are not proactive even when they know a change is on the horizon and could be prepared. 

I have been a victim of unfair pay practices, newly promoted employees into my position being given the position without meeting the experience and job requirements, and then even being given pay that is several dollars above me...even though I trained the employee and they do not  even begin to do most of the tasks I am required to in the position, and honestly couldn't do because they do not have the appropriate skill set or system knowledge. 

Reviews and promotions are based on popularity with your direct supervisor, not measurable objectives and outcomes. So, hope your supervisor likes you, and beyond that is willing to fight their peers for your raise.

HR will ignore employees who bring these pay and promotion issues to them. Or they will direct you to your supervisor, even if that is the person you have an issue with.

More and more of their work is being outsourced to over seas companies in India, but they make every effort to hide that from customers. For example, a letter sent to a member from an onshore employee will have that employee's signature, but that same letter sent from an off shore worker will show the department managers signature...makes sense only if you don't want customers to know you outsourced your work to India.

They will push political agendas onto their employees with emails from upper management, etc. All claiming they're trying to give you the facts, but fail to give facts about opposing opinions. No employee should ever feel like they're being persuaded to vote one way or another on an issue.

They also won't tell you about the numerous investigations, and lawsuits they're entangled in.

They constantly talk about ethical culture, but truly do not live it. It is just a facade, and when put to the test they fail....they fail in fair pay and employment practices most notably.
